Will be discontinued, as will the

Commencement
Plans Include
Guest Speaker
Commencement exercises will
be held beginning at 10 a.m. on
Tuesday, June 9 with guest Dr.
James R. Killian and University
President Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower as principal speakers.
Dr. Killian, special assistant to
the President of the United
States for science and technology, and on leave of absence as
president of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology, will deliver the main address. Dr.
Eisenhower will confer upon Dr.
Killian an honorary degree and
deliver a Charge to those receiving degrees.
The exercises will be held in
front of Shriver Hall on Wyman
Quadrangle. In case of rain they
will be moved inside Shriver
Hall.
Dr. Donald H. Andrews will
act as Chief Marshal, with Drs.
William D. McElroy and Dayton
E. Carritt as Assistant Marshals.
Graduate and undergraduate
degrees will be granted to students from Homewood, the Medical. Institutions, and the School
International
of
Advanced
Studies in Washington, D. C.

members of several societies and
research councils and has published over 70 scientific publications.
Dr. H. Bentley Glass is also a
Professor of Biology at Johns
Hopkins. He is a member of
numerous societies and academies including the National
Academy of Sciences and holds
the honor of being President of
the American Association of
University Professors. He has
taught at Baylor, Stephans, Columbia, and Goucher. He is recognized as one of the leaders in
the study of biology, especially
genetics in this country, and is
the author of many scientific
articles and reviews.
Dr. F. Clauser is the head of
the Department of Aeronautical
Engineering and former Research Aerodynamicist for the

Douglas Aircraft Company. During the war he participated in
secret research projects for the
Air Force, and has obtained three
degrees from the - California Institute of Technology.
Dr. Lehninger is presently a
Delmar Professor of Physiological Chemistry and Director of
the department at the Johns
Hopkins Medical School. He had
studied and taught at Wesleyan,
Wisconsin, Chicago and Frankfurt before coming to Hopkins
in 1952. In 1951 he received a
Fulbright Fellowship to work at
Trinity College of Cambridge
University in England. He is a
member of numerous scientific
societies including the National
Academy of Sciences. A member
of the editorial boards of several
scientific magazines, Dr. Lehninger has himself published a
great many scientific papers.

The Defense Of An Ideal
The author of the American Mercury's article has
resurrected a few old bones that have already been picked
so clean they don't even smell anymore. One more airing
won't hurt them, but it is a shame that this has become
necessary.
We have come to the conclusion that it is better to
resist the Mercury's accusations passively than actively.
Defending once more our University's stand on academic
freedom is a much more potent argument. Let this, and
the facts concerning Mr. Lattimore, speak for themselves.
Academic freedom involves two principles: the freedom to learn and the freedom to teach. A professor is
dedicated to learning, and where learning leads toward
truth the ways may be various. Honest thought thus
becomes, in the quest for knowledge (and ultimately wisdom) a very real and valid concept. To question thought
is necessary, but to dismiss a professor or any educator

'HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 22, 1959

Gaze Into The Crystal Ball

Take A Peek At The Hopkins Of Tomorrow
(By the Author of"Rally Round the Flag,Boys!"and,1
"Barefoot Boy with Cheek.")

TILL WE MEET AGAIN
This Is the last column of my fifth year of writing for Philip
Morris and Marlboro. I have made it a custom in the last
column of each year not to be funny. I know I have also
realized this aim in many other columns during the year, but
that was not for lack of trying. Today I am not trying. I am not
trying for two reasons: First, because you are getting ready for
final exams and in your present state of shock, nothing in the
world could possibly make you laugh. And second, this final
column of the year is for many of us a leave-taking, and goodbyes always make me too misty to be funny.
For me the year ends neither with a bang nor a whimper, but
with a glow—a warm, pleasant, mellow glow—the kind of glow
you will find, for example, at the end of a Philip Morris or
Marlboro.
It has been in every Way a gratifying experience, my five
years with the makers of Philip Morris and Marlboro, and I
would like to take this 'opportunity" to extend my heartfelt
appreciation to these good tobacconists, to assure _them that
the memory of their kindness will remain ever green in my
heart, and to remind them that they still owe me for the last
three columns.
And in these waning days of the school year, let me address
myself seriously to you, my readers. Have I trod on any toes
this year? Ruffled any feelings? Jostled any sensibilities? If
so, I am sorry.
Have I occasioned any laughs? Chuckles? Sniggers? Mona
Lisa smiles? If so, I'm glad.
Have I persuaded any of you to try Philip- Morris and
Marlboro? To taste that fine flavor? lb smoke that excellent
tobaCco? If so; you are glad.
And now the long, lazy summer lies ahead. But for me summer is never lazy. It is, in fact, the busiest time of year. Two
summers ago, for instance, I was out ringing doorbells every
single day, morning, noon, and night. There was -a contest,
you see, and the kid in my neighborhood who sold the most
bluing won a pony. him proud to report that I was the lucky
winner.
Last summer I was also out ringing doorbells every single
day, morning, noon, and night. I was trying to sell the pony.

This summer I am not going to be out ringing doorbells.
I am going to saddle the pony and ride to Hollywood, California.
What am I going to do in Hollywood, California? I am going to
write a series of half-hour television comedies called THE
MANY LOVES OF DOBIE GILLIS, and starting in October,
1959, your friends and mine, the makers of Philip Morris and
Marlboro, are going to bring you this program over the Columbia Broadcasting System every Tuesday night at 8:30._ Why
don't you speak to your housemother and ask her if she'll let
you stay up to see it?
And now good-bye. For me it's been kicks all the way, and I
hope for you it hasn't been altogether unbearable. Have a good
summer. Stay well. Stay cool. Stay loose.
199, Matz Shulman

*

*

*

For us, the makers of Philip Morris and Marlboro, it's
been kicks too, and we would like to echo kindly old Max's
Parting words: Stay well. Slay cool. Stay loose.

Eddie Jacobs, Ltd.—Baltimore - Philadelphia

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 22, 1959

Honored (?) Journalists SC Appoints Boosters
Gain Pi DE Membership Responsible For Tours
Student Council president Bill
DeVoe announced that the S.C.
Public Relations Committee was
delegating its responsibility for
giving tours to prospective JHU
students to the Booster Club.
The reason for the transfer,
accordhig to Booster Club president, Cloyd Kerchner, was the
"habhazard" manner in which
tours were organized this year,
which indicated a definite need
for "better service."
"We have both the time and
the members," he told the Student Council. Next year, he
promised, the Booster Club will
number over 40 members.
He charged that often this
year tours were conducted by
freshmen because they were the
onlSr students who were either
willing or able, due to time, to
give the tours. He questioned
whether guides such as these
were the best possible men for

men were the type needed for
the job and listened while DeVoe
agreed with him, stating "we
feel they can do a better job."
He added that giving the responsibility to the Booster Club
will relieve the Public Relations
Committee of a major burden
and hence give it more time for
other activities it may have been
forced to neglect this past year.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 22, 1959

NEWS -LETTER

LETTER
PAGE NINE

Hopkins Mt. Washington Tomorrow
Titie-Contending Jays Engage Blue Jay Netmen
Local Aces In Season Finale Win M-D Trophy
After Near Loss
POO

By LEWIS M. SIEGEL
Sports Editor
Hopkins deserves the National Lacrosse Championship.
This corner's opinion is, of
course, prejudiced, but after last
week's crushing defeat of Maryland, not many in the state will
dispute it.
It would be ludicrous to call
a team beaten 20-8 by an opponent co-champion with - that
oPPonent. Maryland has thus
been virtually eliminated from
the title picture. This leaves
Army.
. It is a lacrosse axiom that any
"Up" team can often defeat a
better "down" team. From comparative scores, who can say that
Navy is better than Hopkins?
Navy openly stated that it was
"Shooting for Hopkins alone."
Other than Army, the Jays were
considered their main objective.
The men in Blue were obviously
not at their peak for the Middies, as shown by Hopkins's performance against a much more
formidable opponent last week.
No Drawback
The Army-Maryland contest
had no such drawback. Both
teams admitted that they considered this the battle for the
title. There was no question of
being "down." Maryland was
never behind, the Cadets had to
stage a late rally to make the
score as close as 17-16.
It would be ridiculous to consider an off day by a top club as
bearing equal weight with a
contest when both clubs are "up"
and are openly playing at their
best.
Northern Executive Committee

Obviously looking past the little

ith Hopkins..

"Long-range programs are important
for both men and missiles"
"In a company dedicated to research and development,
a young man's opportunities to learn more—to increase
his technical skills—are almost unlimited," says 31-yearold Harry Lawton, Jr., a General Electric engineer
engaged in the development of inertial guidance and
fire-control systems for ballistic missiles."And to maintain America's scientific leadership, we're going to need
all the technical training and skills we can produce.
"An important aspect of my job at General Electric
is the continuing opportunity to learn more. I've been
able to continue my education in the company's Physics
Program for college graduates. And I also have the
advantage of association with top technical experts in
my work. Opportunities like this have helped me realize that long-range programs are important—for both
men and missiles."
Harry Lawton is one of several hundred technical
graduates who are devoting their skills to the develop-

ment of 14 government missile projects to which General
Electric is a major contributor. More and more our
scientific progress and our national security depend on
men like this — men who bring high qualifications to
their work and who continue their quest for knowledge,
both on and off the job.
General Electric believes that individual initiative
and career growth are essential to America's continued
technological leadership. To this end, the company encourages all of its employees — including more than
30,000 college graduates — to develop to their fullest
capabilities by providing opportunities for increasing
knowledge and working skills.

Commencement
Plans Include
Guest Speaker
Commencement exercises will
be held beginning at 10 a.m. on
Tuesday, June 9 with guest Dr.
James R. Killian and University
President Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower as principal speakers.
Dr. Killian, special assistant to
the President of the United
States for science and technology, and on leave of absence as
president of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology, will deliver the main address. Dr.
Eisenhower will confer upon Dr.
Killian an honorary degree and
deliver a Charge to those receiving degrees.
The exercises will be held in
front of Shriver Hall on Wyman
Quadrangle. In case of rain they
will be moved inside Shriver
Hall.
Dr. Donald H. Andrews will
act as Chief Marshal, with Drs.
William D. McElroy and Dayton
E. Carritt as Assistant Marshals.
Graduate and undergraduate
degrees will be granted to students from Homewood, the Medical. Institutions, and the School
International
of
Advanced
Studies in Washington, D. C.

(Continued from Page 1)
ently Professor of Biology and
Chairman of the Biology Department here at Homewood. He is
also Director of the McCollumPratt Institute, and had studied and taught at Stanford,
Reed, and Princeton before coming to Hopkins in 1945. He is a
members of several societies and
research councils and has published over 70 scientific publications.
Dr. H. Bentley Glass is also a
Professor of Biology at Johns
Hopkins. He is a member of
numerous societies and academies including the National
Academy of Sciences and holds
the honor of being President of
the American Association of
University Professors. He has
taught at Baylor, Stephans, Columbia, and Goucher. He is recognized as one of the leaders in
the study of biology, especially
genetics in this country, and is
the author of many scientific
articles and reviews.
Dr. F. Clauser is the head of
the Department of Aeronautical
Engineering and former Research Aerodynamicist for the

Douglas Aircraft Company. During the war he participated in
secret research projects for the
Air Force, and has obtained three
degrees from the - California Institute of Technology.
Dr. Lehninger is presently a
Delmar Professor of Physiological Chemistry and Director of
the department at the Johns
Hopkins Medical School. He had
studied and taught at Wesleyan,
Wisconsin, Chicago and Frankfurt before coming to Hopkins
in 1952. In 1951 he received a
Fulbright Fellowship to work at
Trinity College of Cambridge
University in England. He is a
member of numerous scientific
societies including the National
Academy of Sciences. A member
of the editorial boards of several
scientific magazines, Dr. Lehninger has himself published a
great many scientific papers.

The Defense Of An Ideal
The author of the American Mercury's article has
resurrected a few old bones that have already been picked
so clean they don't even smell anymore. One more airing
won't hurt them, but it is a shame that this has become
necessary.
We have come to the conclusion that it is better to
resist the Mercury's accusations passively than actively.
Defending once more our University's stand on academic
freedom is a much more potent argument. Let this, and
the facts concerning Mr. Lattimore, speak for themselves.
Academic freedom involves two principles: the freedom to learn and the freedom to teach. A professor is
dedicated to learning, and where learning leads toward
truth the ways may be various. Honest thought thus
becomes, in the quest for knowledge (and ultimately wisdom) a very real and valid concept. To question thought
is necessary, but to dismiss a professor or any educator

Gaze Into The Crystal Ball

Take A Peek At The Hopkins Of Tomorrow
(By the Author of"Rally Round the Flag,Boys!"and,1
"Barefoot Boy with Cheek.")

TILL WE MEET AGAIN
This Is the last column of my fifth year of writing for Philip
Morris and Marlboro. I have made it a custom in the last
column of each year not to be funny. I know I have also
realized this aim in many other columns during the year, but
that was not for lack of trying. Today I am not trying. I am not
trying for two reasons: First, because you are getting ready for
final exams and in your present state of shock, nothing in the
world could possibly make you laugh. And second, this final
column of the year is for many of us a leave-taking, and goodbyes always make me too misty to be funny.
For me the year ends neither with a bang nor a whimper, but
with a glow—a warm, pleasant, mellow glow—the kind of glow
you will find, for example, at the end of a Philip Morris or
Marlboro.
It has been in every Way a gratifying experience, my five
years with the makers of Philip Morris and Marlboro, and I
would like to take this 'opportunity" to extend my heartfelt
appreciation to these good tobacconists, to assure _them that
the memory of their kindness will remain ever green in my
heart, and to remind them that they still owe me for the last
three columns.
And in these waning days of the school year, let me address
myself seriously to you, my readers. Have I trod on any toes
this year? Ruffled any feelings? Jostled any sensibilities? If
so, I am sorry.
Have I occasioned any laughs? Chuckles? Sniggers? Mona
Lisa smiles? If so, I'm glad.
Have I persuaded any of you to try Philip- Morris and
Marlboro? To taste that fine flavor? lb smoke that excellent
tobaCco? If so; you are glad.
And now the long, lazy summer lies ahead. But for me summer is never lazy. It is, in fact, the busiest time of year. Two
summers ago, for instance, I was out ringing doorbells every
single day, morning, noon, and night. There was -a contest,
you see, and the kid in my neighborhood who sold the most
bluing won a pony. him proud to report that I was the lucky
winner.
Last summer I was also out ringing doorbells every single
day, morning, noon, and night. I was trying to sell the pony.

This summer I am not going to be out ringing doorbells.
I am going to saddle the pony and ride to Hollywood, California.
What am I going to do in Hollywood, California? I am going to
write a series of half-hour television comedies called THE
MANY LOVES OF DOBIE GILLIS, and starting in October,
1959, your friends and mine, the makers of Philip Morris and
Marlboro, are going to bring you this program over the Columbia Broadcasting System every Tuesday night at 8:30._ Why
don't you speak to your housemother and ask her if she'll let
you stay up to see it?
And now good-bye. For me it's been kicks all the way, and I
hope for you it hasn't been altogether unbearable. Have a good
summer. Stay well. Stay cool. Stay loose.
199, Matz Shulman

*

*

*

For us, the makers of Philip Morris and Marlboro, it's
been kicks too, and we would like to echo kindly old Max's
Parting words: Stay well. Slay cool. Stay loose.

Eddie Jacobs, Ltd.—Baltimore - Philadelphia

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 22, 1959

Honored (?) Journalists SC Appoints Boosters
Gain Pi DE Membership Responsible For Tours
Student Council president Bill
DeVoe announced that the S.C.
Public Relations Committee was
delegating its responsibility for
giving tours to prospective JHU
students to the Booster Club.
The reason for the transfer,
accordhig to Booster Club president, Cloyd Kerchner, was the
"habhazard" manner in which
tours were organized this year,
which indicated a definite need
for "better service."
"We have both the time and
the members," he told the Student Council. Next year, he
promised, the Booster Club will
number over 40 members.
He charged that often this
year tours were conducted by
freshmen because they were the
onlSr students who were either
willing or able, due to time, to
give the tours. He questioned
whether guides such as these
were the best possible men for

men were the type needed for
the job and listened while DeVoe
agreed with him, stating "we
feel they can do a better job."
He added that giving the responsibility to the Booster Club
will relieve the Public Relations
Committee of a major burden
and hence give it more time for
other activities it may have been
forced to neglect this past year.

Hopkins Mt. Washington Tomorrow
Titie-Contending Jays Engage Blue Jay Netmen
Local Aces In Season Finale Win M-D Trophy
After Near Loss
POO

By LEWIS M. SIEGEL
Sports Editor
Hopkins deserves the National Lacrosse Championship.
This corner's opinion is, of
course, prejudiced, but after last
week's crushing defeat of Maryland, not many in the state will
dispute it.
It would be ludicrous to call
a team beaten 20-8 by an opponent co-champion with - that
oPPonent. Maryland has thus
been virtually eliminated from
the title picture. This leaves
Army.
. It is a lacrosse axiom that any
"Up" team can often defeat a
better "down" team. From comparative scores, who can say that
Navy is better than Hopkins?
Navy openly stated that it was
"Shooting for Hopkins alone."
Other than Army, the Jays were
considered their main objective.
The men in Blue were obviously
not at their peak for the Middies, as shown by Hopkins's performance against a much more
formidable opponent last week.
No Drawback
The Army-Maryland contest
had no such drawback. Both
teams admitted that they considered this the battle for the
title. There was no question of
being "down." Maryland was
never behind, the Cadets had to
stage a late rally to make the
score as close as 17-16.
It would be ridiculous to consider an off day by a top club as
bearing equal weight with a
contest when both clubs are "up"
and are openly playing at their
best.
Northern Executive Committee
Class B Baltimore U. tied Navy
6-6, last week in double overtime. It took the Middies two
goals in the second extra period
to avoid defeat. It would be as
sensible to call Baltimore U. on
a Par with Navy (which was
Obviously looking past the little
City school to arch-rival Army)
as to call Army on a par with
HoPkins just because both teams
have one loss each.
The predominantly northern
executive committee found an
excuse in the point system
(which by order of the U.S.
Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association was to be used only as a
"guide," with records and schednles predominate in consideration) to give Army, a Northern
team, the title last year.
This season there can be no
such crutch for the committee.
The disastrous point system has
been dropped. Their open bias
will be evident for all to see if
Army is picked as co-champion
ith Hopkins..

All-Star Game—
The annual North-South
All Star lacrosse contest will
take Place at Homewood Field
on Friday, June 5, at 9 Pm.
Between halves the winner of
the all-important Wingate
Trophy awarded to the National Lacrosse Champion,
will be announced.
Reserved seats will cost
General admission tickets will cost $1.25. The may be
Purchased at the Athletic
Office.

"Long-range programs are important
for both men and missiles"
"In a company dedicated to research and development,
a young man's opportunities to learn more—to increase
his technical skills—are almost unlimited," says 31-yearold Harry Lawton, Jr., a General Electric engineer
engaged in the development of inertial guidance and
fire-control systems for ballistic missiles."And to maintain America's scientific leadership, we're going to need
all the technical training and skills we can produce.
"An important aspect of my job at General Electric
is the continuing opportunity to learn more. I've been
able to continue my education in the company's Physics
Program for college graduates. And I also have the
advantage of association with top technical experts in
my work. Opportunities like this have helped me realize that long-range programs are important—for both
men and missiles."
Harry Lawton is one of several hundred technical
graduates who are devoting their skills to the develop-

ment of 14 government missile projects to which General
Electric is a major contributor. More and more our
scientific progress and our national security depend on
men like this — men who bring high qualifications to
their work and who continue their quest for knowledge,
both on and off the job.
General Electric believes that individual initiative
and career growth are essential to America's continued
technological leadership. To this end, the company encourages all of its employees — including more than
30,000 college graduates — to develop to their fullest
capabilities by providing opportunities for increasing
knowledge and working skills.
